title: Parts of the body and clothing

children.title: arm
children.comment: Used as a symbol of strength and as a means of expressing affection and relationship. Some ornaments are worn on the arm.

seealsos.comment: carrying
hitting
archery
craftsmanship
teaching to walk

cschildren.title: The arm as a symbol of human strength
The arm as a symbol of human weakness

children.title: Feeble arms need to be strengthened
Human arms are weak compared with God's strength

cschildren.title: The arm of God as a symbol

children.title: Of the power of God to save

cschildren.title: Arms as an expression of affection and greeting

children.title: Used to embrace a wife or lover
Used in phrases expressing the adoption of false gods
back
children.comment: As the part of the body used for bearing loads it is used both literally and metaphorically.

cschildren.title: The human back used for carrying

children.title: Jesus Christ carried his cross on his back

seealsos.comment: The shape of the cross necessitated it being carried across the shoulders and back.  It appears that Jesus Christ started to carry his own cross but Simon of Cyrene took over as Christ weakened.

cschildren.title: Animals carry people and goods on their backs

children.title: Riding on the backs of animals may indicate royalty or privilege
Jesus Christ mounted a donkey for his triumphal entry into Jerusalem

cschildren.title: Carrying a burden on the back represents bearing suffering and trials

children.title: Pain in the back causing anguish
Bending of the back indicates loss of physical strength
Beating on the back is a punishment
Beating on the back may be an unjust punishment for God's servants

seealsos.comment: The servants in the parable represent the OT prophets.

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ becomes the suffering servant of Isaiah's prophecies.

children.title: Jesus Christ's disciples should expect similar flogging
Whipping on the back used figuratively in a warning
Walking over the back used figuratively to indicate defeat
God makes the enemies of his people flee

primaryrefs.comment: ``To turn one's back'', in these verses and the following verses, also implies a lack of respect and reverence for God and his ways.

cschildren.title: Thrusting behind one's back means discarding

primaryrefs.comment: God forgives sins, putting them out of sight

cschildren.title: God turns his back in his grace

primaryrefs.comment: To see God's face would bring death.

cschildren.title: God turns his back against disobedient people

children.title: baldness
children.comment: Loss of hair on the head as the result of natural causes or deliberate action. Baldness may be used to signify judgment, mourning or shame.

cschildren.title: Instructions regarding baldness within Jewish law

seealsos.comment: In pagan Canaan mourners shaved their foreheads.

children.title: Cleansing may involve shaving the head
Vows that involve shaving the head

secondaryrefs.comment: based on the Nazarite rule recorded in Nu 6:1-21
Ezekiel instructed to shave his head to symbolise this

cschildren.title: Baldness as a symbol of mourning

primaryrefs.comment: Job here mourns the loss of his children, household and livestock.

children.title: Used figuratively to indicate the mourning of a nation

cschildren.title: Baldness as a symbol of shame

secondaryrefs.comment: baldness caused by the rubbing of leather helmets in warfare

cschildren.title: Bathing as an act of ritual cleansing
Bathing as a means of cleansing or refreshing the body

primaryrefs.comment: Moab is in mourning.

children.title: Cutting the edges of the beard was forbidden

secondaryrefs.comment: This is a prohibition still adhered to by some Jews today

children.title: belt
children.comment: An item of clothing, worn round the waist, used for gathering clothes and holding weapons or money.

cschildren.title: The belt as an item of clothing
Part of the battledress of a warrior
A leather belt was a sign of rough living
The belt symbolises truth and righteousness

children.title: biting
children.comment: The use of teeth to harm, threaten or express frustration. It is illustrative of the effect of slander, cold wind, excessive wine or of God's judgment.

children.title: Reptiles and animals prevented from biting
Of God's judgment on the wicked
Of the wicked against God's people

seealsos.comment: A fulfilment of the prophecy of Isa 22:13, indicating that the devouring of God's people is a part of the greed of the wicked

children.title: Of the frustration of the wicked
Of the effect of excessive wine
blindness
children.comment: The inability on the part of someone to see properly. Blindness is often used in Scripture as a symbol of human sin.

children.title: blindness, natural
children.comment: The inability to see properly. The healing of such physical blindness was one of the many miracles performed by Jesus Christ, who restored sight to the blind at several points during his ministry. Scripture often treats blindness as a symbol of the human inability or refusal to realise the importance of God and the gospel. The restoration of sight can thus be treated as a symbol of coming to faith.

children.title: Directions to care for the blind
The LORD makes blind eyes see
The healing of the blind by Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: through Ananias

children.title: blindness, spiritual
children.comment: An inability or unwillingness to perceive the truth of the gospel.

seealsos.comment: the spiritual blindness of the Pharisees

children.title: Spiritual blindness is a result of sin

seealsos.comment: lack of success, oppression and robbery
the violence of war
Elisha asks the LORD to open his servant's eyes
No-one can see the kingdom of God without being born again
Jesus Christ is the light of the world

children.title: The spiritual blindness of a church
blindness, natural
children.comment: The inability to see properly. The healing of such physical blindness was one of the many miracles performed by Jesus Christ, who restored sight to the blind at several points during his ministry. Scripture often treats blindness as a symbol of the human inability or refusal to realise the importance of God and the gospel. The restoration of sight can thus be treated as a symbol of coming to faith.

children.title: Directions to care for the blind
The LORD makes blind eyes see
The healing of the blind by Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: through Ananias

children.title: blindness, spiritual
children.comment: An inability or unwillingness to perceive the truth of the gospel.

seealsos.comment: the spiritual blindness of the Pharisees

children.title: Spiritual blindness is a result of sin

seealsos.comment: lack of success, oppression and robbery
the violence of war
Elisha asks the LORD to open his servant's eyes
No-one can see the kingdom of God without being born again
Jesus Christ is the light of the world

children.title: The spiritual blindness of a church
body
children.comment: Used in Scripture in both a physical and metaphorical sense, the body is susceptible to sin and suffering, but may be offered to God in worship and will finally be transformed by resurrection.

cschildren.title: The body is formed by God

children.title: The beauty and strength of the body

cschildren.title: Certain actions and attitudes affect the health of the body

children.title: Godliness is no guarantee of bodily health

primaryrefs.comment: Suffering and death are the result of sin in general, but specific experiences of suffering cannot usually be traced to specific sin.

cschildren.title: Life here and now in the body
The believer's body as a temple of the Holy Spirit

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ also likens his body to a temple

cschildren.title: Believers are to devote their bodies to God
Sin at work in the body

children.title: The body is subject to sinful desires
Bodily temptation is to be resisted
Undue concern for the body is to be avoided
Dead bodies restored to this life
bones
children.comment: Associated in Hebrew thought with both death and life. A symbol of the whole person, and also the state of one's well-being.

children.title: Human remains to be treated with respect
Non-burial as a sign of disrespect
Non-burial as a sign of God's judgment

cschildren.title: Bones were considered to be unclean

children.title: Bones made anyone who touched them unclean
Bones used to desecrate objects of pagan worship

cschildren.title: Bones as a sign of hope

seealsos.comment: The presence of Joseph's bones among the Israelites was a constant reminder of God's promise to Joseph concerning the promised land.

children.title: The hope of life after death
The hope of the Passover lamb

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ fulfilled the symbolism of the unbroken bones of the Passover lamb.

primaryrefs.comment: ``My whole being'' is literally ``my bones''.

children.title: Mere skin and bone represents bad health
Broken bones symbolise defeat or oppression
Health can be damaged by negative attitudes
Health can be damaged by sin
Health can be damaged through obedience to God's will
bowing
children.comment: An act of submission before something or someone deemed worthy of honour.

cschildren.title: Bowing as an act of submission

primaryrefs.comment: The temple represented God's presence.

cschildren.title: Bowing as an expression of sorrow

children.title: bracelet
children.comment: An expensive ornamental armlet usually worn by women.

children.title: breasts
children.comment: On a woman, the bosom; on a man the upper part of the chest. Female breasts are primarily referred to as a means of feeding young and as a figurative description of Israel and God as nursing mothers. Beating of the breast is a sign of remorse. The breast is protected in physical and spiritual warfare.

cschildren.title: Breasts as a symbol of fertility
Breasts as the means of feeding young

seealsos.comment: until they are weaned
``Nursing'' includes breast-feeding.

children.title: Nursing mothers and their children experience acute distress

seealsos.comment: The implication is that children nursing at their mothers' breasts are completely vulnerable and defenceless.

children.title: Breasts are a source of temptation
Undeveloped breasts are a sign of youth

primaryrefs.comment: The two sisters are Samaria and Jerusalem.

seealsos.comment: Gomer's unfaithfulness is likened to that of Israel.

children.title: Dry breasts are a sign of God's punishment

cschildren.title: God's care exceeds that of nursing mothers

seealsos.comment: The Gentiles will be used by God to provide nursing for Israel.

children.title: Breastplates worn for protection in confrontations

cschildren.title: Animal breasts used in sacrificial offerings

children.title: cheeks
children.comment: Literally, the parts either side of the face. Striking the cheek is an extreme form of insult.

cschildren.title: Cheeks can bear symbols of grief
Striking the cheek is a form of insult or challenge
Plucking the beard from the cheek is a form of insult

children.title: clapping
children.comment: Applauding with one's hands, as an expression of delight. Scripture portrays even the creation sharing in this delight at the majesty of its Creator.

cschildren.title: Clapping as an expression of delight

children.title: Expressing the delight of the creation in its Creator

cschildren.title: Clapping as an act of derision

primaryrefs.comment: Because Jerusalem was built at a high elevation, going to worship there usually involved ascent.

children.title: cloak
children.comment: A protective outer garment, often treated as a symbol of authority.

cschildren.title: The cloak used as a garment

seealsos.comment: A woman's bleeding is stopped

cschildren.title: The cloak used as a covering or blanket

primaryrefs.comment: This constituted an act of royal homage.

children.title: The cloak torn as a symbol of mourning
clothing
children.comment: Garments were originally provided by God for Adam and Eve. Kings and priests were given special garments. God's people should neither be unduly anxious about how they dress, nor judge others by what they wear. Inner clothing is more important than outer adornment.

cschildren.title: Rich clothing a sign of wealth or status
The Israelites' clothing did not wear out in the desert wanderings
Clothing as a symbol of fragility and perishability

children.title: The hem or corner of a garment

secondaryrefs.comment: The corner of a garment spread over a person denotes protection and possession.

cschildren.title: Provision of rich clothing a picture of God's love

children.title: The dress of Elijah and John the Baptist
Isaiah's lack of clothing a prophetic sign
The mock robing of Jesus Christ
Gambling at the cross for Jesus Christ's clothing

cschildren.title: Believers not to be unduly anxious about clothing
Believers not to discriminate because of clothing
Inner clothing more important than outer adornment
White clothing, the clothing of heaven

children.title: The vision of the exalted Christ
covering
children.comment: That which literally or metaphorically hides from the human or divine eye what should not be seen.

cschildren.title: Covering as a sign of submission or humility

seealsos.comment: Some suggest that this passage refers either to a woman's modesty or to her dignity considering her new Christian status of equality with man.

cschildren.title: The covering of human sin through atonement

seealsos.comment: The word translated ``atonement'' literally means ``covering''

children.title: deafness
children.comment: The condition of being wholly, or partly, without hearing. It can be expressed in physical or spiritual terms and is often used to depict spiritual rebellion.

children.title: God deaf to a rebellious people

seealsos.comment: Sin brings spiritual deafness.

children.title: Through the coming of Jesus Christ
ear
children.comment: The organ of hearing; the ear is referred to in various OT rites and is a symbol of attention, alertness or readiness to hear.

cschildren.title: The ear in the OT rites

children.title: Piercing the ear: a symbol of servanthood
Blood applied to the ear: a symbol of cleansing and ordination

cschildren.title: God's ear as a symbol of his alertness to humanity
God's ear may be turned away from humanity

primaryrefs.comment: The refusal to turn an ear towards someone was a symbol of refusing to listen.

seealsos.comment: God's attending ear is partly dependent on human attitudes to him.

children.title: Human ears should be open to God

seealsos.comment: ``He who has ears'' implies a potential willingness to listen

children.title: Human ears may be closed against God
The human ear should also be open to others

cschildren.title: A discerning ear brings knowledge and understanding

children.title: eyes
children.comment: The part of the body designed for seeing.  In Scripture eyes are often associated with light, watchfulness or spiritual understanding, whereas blindness may be a metaphor for darkness, ignorance of God or rebellion against him.  The eyes of God watch over all his creation.

cschildren.title: Eyes are part of the physical body

children.title: Eyes may represent the whole person
Eyes may have a powerful emotional effect
Eyes reflect character, feelings and emotions

cschildren.title: God's eyes are upon all his creation

children.title: God watches over his people with care
God's eyes symbolise his assessment of human behaviour

cschildren.title: Human eyes may symbolise spiritual vision

children.title: God opens eyes in a spiritual sense

primaryrefs.comment: The ``opening of eyes'' is an important biblical metaphor for revelation

children.title: Human eyes should be directed towards God

primaryrefs.comment: Lifting one's eyes towards God is an important biblical image of prayer.

cschildren.title: Human eyes will ultimately see God
Eyes are a channel of temptation

children.title: Eyes should be guarded against evil

seealsos.comment: The direction of human eyes is a matter of choice.

cschildren.title: Closing one's eyes may symbolise indifference to God and his will

children.title: face
children.comment: The main visual characteristic of a person. Facial features are recognisable as uniquely those of a particular person. The face also indicates mood and attitude. The showing or directing of the face towards someone or something may indicate regard, approval or determination, while hiding or turning away of the face indicates the opposite.

cschildren.title: The face is the main recognisable feature of a person

children.title: Examples of failure to recognise faces

seealsos.comment: There is no evidence to suggest that Jesus Christ's post-resurrection face was different.

children.title: The face may be used symbolically to represent the whole person
The face expresses a person's mood
Averting the face may express worship, respect, modesty or shame

secondaryrefs.comment: the literal translation is ``set his face to go''

cschildren.title: Other gestures involving the human face

children.title: Hiding the face from someone as a sign of loss of favour
Raising the face as a sign of lack of shame
Slapping someone's face as a challenge or insult
Spitting in someone's face as an insult
Not seeing someone's face may indicate rejection
Seeking the LORD's face means seeking his will
God's face may be turned away, hidden or set against people as a sign of opposition or removal from favour
People cannot normally see God's face

seealsos.comment: In the end all human beings will see God face to face.

cschildren.title: ``Face of the earth'' indicates the earth's total area

children.title: feet
children.comment: The part of the body associated with moving and with foundation, direction and chosen path. Feet may symbolise the response to God's direction. The feet of God and of Jesus Christ are mentioned symbolically to describe some divine characteristics.

cschildren.title: Feet as part of the physical body

children.title: The feet of creatures and objects of worship

cschildren.title: A whole person may be represented by the foot

children.title: In relation to guidance, direction and following
In relation to disobedience and waywardness
In relation to a secure standing with God
In relation to bringing the gospel
In relation to expressing attitudes and emotions

secondaryrefs.comment: scorn and a warning to those who reject God's message

cschildren.title: ``Jesus' feet'' symbolises the source and place of God's grace

children.title: Worshippers come to Jesus Christ's feet
The sinful come to Jesus Christ's feet
The suffering come to Jesus Christ's feet
People sit at Jesus Christ's feet to learn

primaryrefs.comment: It was common practice for disciples to gather around their teacher in this way.

children.title: Ultimately all will come to Jesus Christ's feet in worship

cschildren.title: ``Feet of God'' symbolises his majestic presence

children.title: God's feet are referred to in relation to worship

cschildren.title: ``Beneath/under the feet'' to denote the defeat and subservience of enemies

children.title: fingers
children.comment: Parts of the hand used in various kinds of activity, both good and bad. They were prominent in the OT sacrificial ritual, and were also used as a symbol for authority, accusation and minimum effort.

children.title: In the ritual for the sin offering
In the ritual of the Day of Atonement

cschildren.title: The finger as a unit of measurement

children.title: Jesus Christ heals with his fingers
Jesus Christ writes with his fingers
The finger ring as a sign of authority
The finger as a symbol of minimal effort

seealsos.comment: Rehoboam refusing to lift the burdens placed on the people by his father Solomon

children.title: The finger as a visible reminder
foot-washing
children.comment: A practice of hospitality used by Jesus Christ to express his servanthood.

cschildren.title: Foot-washing as a sign of courteous hospitality
Jesus Christ washes his disciples' feet

primaryrefs.comment: The washing of feet was a lowly task normally performed by a servant.

children.title: As an example of servanthood for his followers
As a symbol of spiritual cleansing
forehead
children.comment: The front of the head between the eyes. Often used figuratively in phrases denoting a stubborn or persevering attitude. The forehead is the place where symbols of remembrance or allegiance can be placed. Such symbols may particularly represent allegiance to God or Satan.

cschildren.title: The forehead used figuratively to denote stubbornness
The forehead as a place for symbols which prompt remembrance
The forehead as a place for symbols of dedication and allegiance

seealsos.comment: The receipt of this symbol of allegiance provides protection in judgment and a reminder of the Passover where God's marked people escaped judgment.

children.title: hair
children.comment: Various conditions, both physical and spiritual, are indicated in Scripture by human hair. Animal hair is used for a variety of purposes.

children.title: Grey hair shows the glory of old age

seealsos.comment: ``aged'' may be translated ``grey-haired''

children.title: Greying hair as a sign of declining strength
White hair as a sign of age and wisdom

cschildren.title: Hair as indicating physical or spiritual conditions

children.title: Hair standing on end indicates fear
Hair colour may indicate skin disease

cschildren.title: Rituals and customs involving the hair

children.title: Rules concerning hair for those under a vow
Rules concerning hair for those being cleansed
Grief signified by tearing or cutting one's hair
Humiliating others by shaving or pulling out the hair
Customs concerning hair and public worship
Animal hair used in tabernacle furnishings
A prophet's clothing made from animal hair

cschildren.title: Hair used to wipe Jesus Christ's feet
Nazirite vows forbade the cutting of hair

children.title: The reason for taking a Nazirite vow, separation to the Lord

secondaryrefs.comment: While attention is often focused on Nazirite prohibitions, it is important to note that the primary reason was for separating oneself to God. Both men and women could make the vow

children.title: The requirements of the Nazirite vow

secondaryrefs.comment: Nazirites must abstain from all produce of the vine
Nazirites must not cut their hair
Nazirites must not touch a dead body.

children.title: The rules for re-establishing a broken Nazirite vow
The regulations for completing the Nazirite vow

secondaryrefs.comment: The Nazirite vow is completed, first, through prescribed sacrifices
The Nazirite vow is completed, second, through cutting off one's hair and burning it on the altar
The Nazirite vow is completed, third, through ritual acts performed by the priest.

children.title: Examples of people dedicated to being lifelong Nazirites

secondaryrefs.comment: John the Baptist was possibly a Nazirite.

children.title: Nazirites to be seen as gifts from God to his people
hand
children.comment: Associated in Scripture with various activities, the hand symbolises particularly power and strength. Jesus Christ's hands often bring healing and blessing.

cschildren.title: The hand as part of the physical body

children.title: Hands as a means of assistance
Right hand as the place of honour
Significant uses of the left hand
The hand as a symbol of power
The hand as a symbol of violence
Clean hands as a symbol of innocence
Limp hands as a symbol of paralysing fear
Hands as a symbol of temptation
Joining hands in partnership or fellowship
Jesus Christ's hands used in healing
Jesus Christ's hands used in blessing
head
children.comment: The position of the head often expresses an attitude or emotion. Figuratively head may mean ``chief'', ``first'' or ``top''.

cschildren.title: The head as part of the body
The head as the uppermost part of the body

children.title: A crown worn on the head
A turban worn on the head

cschildren.title: Head used figuratively in various expressions

children.title: ``Be it on one's own head'': personal responsibility that is inescapable
``To come back on one's own head'': a wrongdoer suffering the very wrong he or she has committed
``To heap burning coals on his head'': generosity towards an enemy in the hope of causing a change of heart
``Not a hair on one's head will be lost'': absolute safety
``Making it up out of one's head'': imagining something

cschildren.title: Covering or uncovering the head in Christian worship
Expressions of grief involving the head
Various attitudes expressed with the head

children.title: Lifting up the head in joy and expectation
Hanging the head in shame and dejection
The head of a family, tribe or kingdom
Head of a stalk of grain
head-covering
children.comment: A form of clothing worn on the head, often as a sign of status or rank.

primaryrefs.comment: NIV footnote gives an alternative translation for these verses, taking hair as the head-covering.

children.title: hearing
children.comment: In Scripture, both physical hearing and spiritual apprehension. God hears the prayers of his people and the cry of the oppressed. People must hear and respond to God's word.

children.title: God hears the prayers of his people
God hears the grumbling of his people
God hears the cry of the oppressed
God does not hear the unrighteous
The importance of hearing God's word
The gospel must not only be heard but accepted and acted on
It is God who grants effective hearing
Some people refuse to hear God's word
God denies the effective hearing of his word to those who stubbornly resist him

cschildren.title: The first Christians witnessed to what they had heard
Physical hearing was restored by Jesus Christ
The dead will hear the voice of the Son of God
The heel as a vulnerable part of the body
``Lifting up one's heel'' as a metaphor of betrayal
Jacob grasps Esau by the heel at birth

secondaryrefs.comment: Jacob's name means ``he grasps the heel'' which, figuratively, means ``he deceives''

children.title: kneeling
children.comment: A bodily posture which expresses an attitude of humility, especially in worship, prayer or submission to the authority of another person.

seealsos.comment: kneeling in mock submission

children.title: lameness
children.comment: A physical condition impairing leg movement.

children.title: As a parallel to fools' words
legs
children.comment: The legs of an animal were among the choice parts offered in sacrifices. In a human being legs provide strength. Bowing the knee symbolises the submitting of one's human strength to God's control.

cschildren.title: Choice parts of a sacrificial animal

seealsos.comment: burnt outside the camp in the sin offering

cschildren.title: Legs of human beings are objects of beauty
Legs of human beings symbolise strength

children.title: God's judgment brings pain and disgrace
God gives strength to the weak

cschildren.title: The legs of Jesus Christ were not broken at his death
Lips as part of the human body

children.title: As a means of eating and drinking

cschildren.title: Lips associated with various kinds of speech

children.title: Lips that speak promises and vows

cschildren.title: Lips must be watched over by God

children.title: People must guard their own lips
listening
children.comment: People are called upon to listen attentively to God's word, to his Son and also to words of wisdom. Christians must not only listen to God's word but also put it into practice. Those who refuse to listen to God's word or to correction are condemned.

children.title: To God's word and his spokesmen

cschildren.title: Believers should not listen to false prophets or ungodly suggestions
The wicked refuse to listen to God

seealsos.comment: Pharaoh's refusal to listen

cschildren.title: Those who refuse to listen to correction are condemned
God's people must not only listen to God's word but also put it into practice

primaryrefs.comment: In Hebrew and Greek the verb ``listen'' is related by the verb ``to obey''.

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ to the teachers of the law

cschildren.title: The liver and kidneys as vital internal organs of the body
The liver and kidneys are symbolic of human emotions and the conscience

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew words for liver and kidneys are occasionally translated as ``heart'', ``spirit'' or ``inmost being''.

children.title: God examines the innermost being as symbolised by the kidneys
God is concerned for the innermost being as symbolised by the kidneys

cschildren.title: The liver and kidneys as offered in animal sacrifice

children.title: Liver and kidneys offered in various sacrifices

primaryrefs.comment: The liver and kidneys are associated with the fat as the choice parts of the animal.

children.title: Liver and kidneys had a central role in the ordination services for priests

cschildren.title: Divination by inspection of the liver

secondaryrefs.comment: Divination by inspection of the liver (hepatoscopy) was a common practice. The future was predicted from the colour and configuration of the liver of a sacrificial animal, usually a sheep.

children.title: mouth
children.comment: In addition to its normal physical functions, it has great potential for good and evil. The words of God's mouth are always effective. Mouth is also used in the sense of an entrance or opening.

cschildren.title: God puts his words into the mouths of his people
The mouth used for eating and drinking

children.title: God controls the mouths of dangerous animals

secondaryrefs.comment: Clapping the hand over the mouth signifies keeping silent from fear or astonishment
``the grave'' is literally ``Sheol'', the shadowy abode of the departed.

children.title: muteness
children.comment: The inability to speak or to make sounds comprehensible as speech.

children.title: A disability, sometimes associated with demon-possession, healed by Jesus Christ
God may impose muteness in judgment

cschildren.title: Spiritual aspects of muteness and silence

children.title: God opens believers' mouths in praise

cschildren.title: Nakedness was innocent before the fall
The shame of nakedness a result of the fall
Public exposure of nakedness is indicative of shame or humiliation
Exposure of nakedness is symbolic of adultery and prostitution
Nakedness is symbolic of dire poverty
The neck may express human pride

children.title: An outstretched neck as a sign of pride
Placing the foot on the neck as a sign of conquest

cschildren.title: Ornaments were hung around the neck
A millstone placed around the neck as punishment
The nose as part of the human body

children.title: Human life is given and sustained through the nostrils
The nose and the sense of smell

cschildren.title: Animals snort and sniff through their noses
The nose as an object of beauty

children.title: The nose may be adorned with rings

cschildren.title: The nose is vulnerable to attack
Captives are led by rings or hooks in the nose
Contempt is communicated by means of the nose
Offence is taken, metaphorically, by the nose
God's power is indicated by the blast of his nostrils

children.title: offal
children.comment: The internal organs of an animal, traditionally regarded as being inferior to meat, and used as a symbol of disgrace.

cschildren.title: In animal sacrifices the offal was removed and burnt outside the camp
Jesus Christ bears the believer's disgrace

children.title: outward appearance
children.comment: That which is visible on the outside may reveal the true person, but is sometimes misleading. Judging by it and boasting in it are typical of sinful humanity. God sees the inner reality.

cschildren.title: Outward appearance can reveal the truth
While people may judge by outward appearance, God does not

children.title: People take note of outward appearance

cschildren.title: The folly of boasting in outward appearance
What is unseen is more important than outward appearance

children.title: Examples of the problems and opportunities caused by beautiful outward appearance

secondaryrefs.comment: Sarah's beauty led to Abraham's folly
Joseph's handsome appearance led to his being tempted by Potiphar's wife
Esther's beauty was an opportunity for God.

children.title: The cultivation of inner beauty encouraged
prostration
children.comment: The act of falling down upon one's face in front of someone, as a gesture of fear or reverence before God or a person of high rank.

children.title: As an expression of grieving over sin
reading
children.comment: The gaining of information through written documents. The Law was read regularly in the synagogue. Jesus Christ expected the Scriptures to be read. NT letters were read in the churches to which they were sent.

cschildren.title: Reading of the Law to Israel
Reading of the Law in the synagogue

secondaryrefs.comment: Daniel foresaw the end of the exile through reading the Scriptures.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ expected the Scriptures to be read

children.title: To understand the truth about Jesus Christ
To believe and be saved from God's wrath
To learn how to serve and please God
They teach Christians and give them hope
They enable Christians to discern truth from error
ring
children.comment: An ornament or a status symbol, sometimes used in sacred furnishings or as a charm.

children.title: Gold nose rings, worn especially by women
children.precomment: These were often given by a suitor as a symbol of betrothal:

children.title: The signet ring as a sign of authority
Gold ear-rings, worn by men and women
children.precomment: Ear-rings were sometimes used as charms or amulets:

cschildren.title: Rings as indications of wealth or status

children.title: On the ark of the covenant
robes
children.comment: A formal style of clothing, often indicating priesthood, royalty or elevated social status.

children.title: Jesus Christ robed as a king and mocked

cschildren.title: Robes indicating office, favour or wealth
Robes associated with righteousness and purity
Tearing of robes to show mourning or repentance

children.title: running
children.comment: Scripture gives pictures of running in both its literal and metaphorical senses, the image of the Christian life as a race being particularly significant.

cschildren.title: Heralds running ahead of a dignitary
The life of the believer likened to running a race

children.title: sandal
children.comment: A form of open shoe worn in warm climates, and the only form of foot-covering to be of major importance in Scripture. Both the wearing and the removal of sandals is often seen as symbolic; to go barefoot was often a sign of shame, mourning or poverty.

cschildren.title: Sandals were normally worn by an official, soldier or messenger
Untying and carrying sandals was the task of a servant

primaryrefs.comment: John considers himself unworthy even to be a slave of Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: The removal of sandals as a gesture

children.title: As a mark of respect in the presence of God
To show rejection of any claim to property
To predict the defeat and disgrace of Egypt and Assyria
As a sign of mourning and repentance
As symbols of readiness for action
As symbols of oppression and injustice
Fine sandals as a status symbol

cschildren.title: Sandals as an example of the need for minimum possessions in God's service

children.title: shaving
children.comment: The removal of hair with a razor or other sharp implement. Both male and female Israelites allowed their hair to grow long. Barbers trimmed, but did not crop, men's hair, so giving special significance to the shaving of the head or whole body. These actions indicated shame or grief.

children.title: Shaved head a sign of grief
A shaved head a sign of shame

seealsos.comment: Pagans shaved the front of their heads as a sign of mourning.  God's people should have a different attitude to bereavement from those who have no hope

children.title: For the sake of a Nazarite vow
sitting
children.comment: A bodily posture associated with resting, eating or instruction. When used of God, the image often conveys the idea of kingly authority over creation.

cschildren.title: Sitting to teach or to learn
Sitting as a sign of authority
Sitting as a sign of possession and peace
Jesus Christ seated at God's right hand

children.title: skin
children.comment: The outer covering of the body. Diseased skin is often subject to pain and regarded as unclean.

cschildren.title: Skin as the outer covering of the body

primaryrefs.comment: To be reduced to skin and bones is a mark of severe suffering.

seealsos.comment: animal skins used for covering the ark of the Testimony

cschildren.title: A person can know God even when the skin has been destroyed

children.title: smell
children.comment: An aroma; God is pleased by the aroma of sacrifice, whether a literal sacrifice or the figurative offering of Christian service is a picture of its acceptability to him. Bad smells can indicate physical decay or the results of judgment. To be a stench to someone is to be held in contempt or hated by that person.

seealsos.comment: offerings to be made for unintentional breaking of the LORD's commandments

children.title: Substances to create a pleasing smell
The aroma of sacrifice is not always pleasing to God
Jesus Christ was the supreme fragrant offering

cschildren.title: God accepts his people as fragrant incense
A pleasing aroma depicts acceptable Christian service
Fragrance associated with the expression of love

primaryrefs.comment: The beloved's garden is an image of her body.

seealsos.comment: Manna soon smelled bad if kept. This meant the Israelites had to trust God afresh for each day's supply.

children.title: As the result of God's judgment
children.precomment: The first plague on Egypt, which made the Nile smell bad:

children.title: As a picture of the results of judgment
As a figurative cause of contempt or hatred
standing
children.comment: The bodily posture of being in a stationary upright position.

cschildren.title: Standing as a sign of authority
Standing merely to wait or rest
Standing to show respect or honour
Standing in the presence of God

children.title: stomach
children.comment: As well as the physical stomach, the term is used in association with God's judgment or in a figurative sense.

cschildren.title: Stomach as part of the physical body

children.title: Jonah in the stomach of a huge fish
Crawling on one's stomach as a sign of submission

primaryrefs.comment: Part of God's curse upon Satan.

children.title: Hunger as a result of God's judgment
An empty stomach as a warning

cschildren.title: The stomach and God's blessing
cschildren.precomment: In the OT a full stomach was one sign of God's blessing:

children.title: Stomach as a symbol of inner thoughts
Stomach as a symbol of worldliness
Stomach as something to be filled
stumbling
children.comment: Faltering or falling in the course of running or walking. The term is also used metaphorically to refer to failure, hesitation or difficulty.

cschildren.title: God protects his people from stumbling
The enemies of God's people will stumble
God's people will stumble if they sin
Avoiding stumbling by keeping God's law
The wicked stumble because they reject God's way
Stumbling as a consequence of sin and divine judgment

children.title: Stumbling over obstacles sent by God
Some stumbling is educative or disciplinary

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as the light that prevents believers from stumbling
Jesus Christ as a stumbling-block for unbelievers

children.title: None should feel superior to others
None should cause others to stumble
taste
children.comment: The act of tasting is used figuratively of experiencing the goodness of God and his word and of a variety of experiences: misery, sin, wisdom, love, death and blessing.

cschildren.title: The taste of food or drink
Legalistic prohibitions against tasting certain foods are condemned by Paul

primaryrefs.comment: In his complaint against God, Job compares the unacceptability of his lot to inedible food.

children.title: Of the experience of the goodness of God
Of the experience of the goodness of the word of God
Of the effectiveness of Christian influence
Of the blessings of the kingdom of God

cschildren.title: To determine not to taste food until a task was completed was commonly used as an oath

children.title: tearing of clothes
children.comment: Primarily associated with mourning, such action was an expression of deep sorrow and heartfelt grief. It was also a natural reaction at times of great distress and in cases of sincere repentance.

cschildren.title: The tearing of clothes was a sign of mourning

children.title: It was a demonstration of grief
It was often associated with wearing sackcloth
The high priest was forbidden to tear his clothes in mourning

cschildren.title: The tearing of clothes indicated deep distress

primaryrefs.comment: Jephthah had vowed to sacrifice whatever came out of the door of his house to meet him.

cschildren.title: Repentance was sometimes accompanied by the tearing of clothes

seealsos.comment: an indication of the lack of repentance
God requires that the tearing of clothes should express genuine repentance.

cschildren.title: Other references to the tearing of clothes

children.title: To stop the spread of mildew
As a symbol of the dividing of the kingdom
teeth
children.comment: Scripture often uses teeth symbolically, to refer to the power of individuals or to human rage (as in the ``gnashing of teeth'').

children.title: God rescues his people from the teeth of their enemies
Breaking the teeth of the wicked ends their power

seealsos.comment: Enemies are often described as dangerous animals.

children.title: The hand is placed under the thigh when taking an oath
The priests' undergarments covered the thigh
The wasting of the thigh
children.precomment: The wasting away of the thigh is part of the judgment on an unfaithful wife:

children.title: The thigh as a place of identification

cschildren.title: The right thighs of animals used in sacrificial offerings

children.title: thought
children.comment: The human ability to reason and reflect. Believers are called to reflect upon the words and works of God as they are made known through Scripture and to avoid speculation based purely upon human reason.

children.title: God's thoughts are infinitely higher than human thoughts

cschildren.title: Warnings against founding faith on speculative thought or human wisdom
Believers are to give thought to others

children.title: To think about, and learn from, their shortcomings

cschildren.title: Believers are to give thought to themselves

children.title: To think accurately about themselves and their God-given abilities
To think about their shortcomings and temptations
To think rightly about their plans and ambitions

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ wanted his followers to consider carefully the cost of being a disciple

cschildren.title: The role of the thumb in sacrificial ritual

children.title: tongue
children.comment: The organ of speech, which Scripture stresses can be the source of both praise and blame. The tongue is to be kept under control, on account of its capacity for evil words.

cschildren.title: The tongue as a bodily organ
The tongue as an organ of speech

children.title: God is able to loose the tongue of the mute
As a mark of respect and awe
Right use of the tongue requires an act of the will
The tongue can speak God-given words
The tongue's power needs to be controlled
Other evil uses of the tongue
The punishment for a perverse tongue

cschildren.title: Tongue in the sense of language

children.title: As a language given by the Holy Spirit

cschildren.title: Metaphors used to describe the tongue

children.title: The tongue as a dangerous weapon
touch
children.comment: God prohibits physical contact in certain circumstances and warns of serious consequences of violating the ritual law in this respect. Great sigificance is attached to the touch of God, Jesus Christ and angels and the disciples' touching of the risen Christ.

cschildren.title: God's prohibits touch in certain circumstances

children.title: With the furnishings and articles of the tabernacle

cschildren.title: The law concerning touching certain articles

children.title: Anyone or anything touching what is ritually unclean also becomes unclean

seealsos.comment: the law concerning dead bodies
Pigs are unclean

children.title: Touching what is purified confers consecration

cschildren.title: Man-made rules against touching certain things are condemned by Paul

children.title: Upon those he calls to be prophets
Upon the world he has made, to display his glory

primaryrefs.comment: In touching the dead, Jesus Christ shows his willingness to become unclean so that others can be healed.

children.title: To bring reassurance and show acceptance

cschildren.title: The reality of Jesus Christ's incarnation and resurrection is confirmed by touch

children.title: veil
children.comment: Generally, an item of female dress worn by an unmarried woman in the presence of her future husband and also by a prostitute. Head-coverings were worn by men and women as a sign of mourning. The term is also used metaphorically to indicate a lack of understanding of God's truth. Scripture uses the imagery of ``removing a veil'' to refer to God's final self-revelation at the end of the age, or the making known of God's will and nature through Jesus Christ or other means.

cschildren.title: The veil as an item of female dress

primaryrefs.comment: The veil covered the lower part of the face, so focusing attention on the eyes and temples.

seealsos.comment: Rebekah veils herself in the presence of her future husband, Isaac

children.title: Worn as a sign of wealth and status

secondaryrefs.comment: Babylon's veil will be removed as a mark of her humiliation.

cschildren.title: Veils worn as a sign of grief

children.title: Faces covered in sorrow and dismay

seealsos.comment: A veil worn by the ceremonially unclean signifies grief at separation from God

children.title: Faces covered as a sign of disgrace

primaryrefs.comment: A man's uncovered head in worship signifies submission to his spiritual head, i.e., Jesus Christ
A woman's covered head signifies proper submission to her husband.

cschildren.title: God's sight of humanity is not veiled

children.title: The wicked foolishly boast that God does not see them
God's people complain that God does not see their suffering
People's deeds will be made known

cschildren.title: The truth about God is sometimes veiled

primaryrefs.comment: After speaking with God, Moses' face was radiant; the veil, possibly a loose part of his clothing pulled over his face, prevented the Israelites from seeing that the radiance did not last.

children.title: Lack of understanding of God's truth
God's hidden truth is revealed to believers
God's self-revelation at the end of the age
voice
children.comment: The organ of speech; someone's voice expresses a person's character, thoughts and emotions, and attracts attention by its tone and volume.

children.title: Groups of people speaking in unison
Voices that give a battle cry
Assurance that God hears his people's voice
God's response to his people's voice
God sometimes refuses to hear his people's voice

cschildren.title: The futility of lifting up one's voice to an idol

primaryrefs.comment: The original sense of the voice of the heavens is reapplied to all who proclaim the gospel.

children.title: His voice calls people to him
The voices of the natural world
walking
children.comment: The action of travelling on foot at a normal pace. The image of walking with God is used in Scripture to represent the behaviour of believers in their relationship with God.

cschildren.title: Walking used figuratively of human behaviour

children.title: Walking in the truth or in the light
Walking as a way of living or behaving
weeping
children.comment: The physical act of shedding tears as the result of sadness or joy or in recognition of sin.

seealsos.comment: David weeps for Absalom
David and his men mourn for Saul and Jonathan

cschildren.title: Weeping in personal remorse over failure and sin
Weeping in group response to sin

seealsos.comment: the people's response to the rebuilding of the temple

cschildren.title: Weeping in response to others' sin and judgment

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ weeps over Jerusalem

cschildren.title: Comfort promised to those who weep

children.title: womb
children.comment: The part of the female body where offspring are conceived and developed. A barren womb can be indicative of God's displeasure or a test of faith, while a fruitful womb may be a sign of his favour. It is God who creates within the womb. In ancient Israel, the first offspring of every womb belonged to God.

cschildren.title: The womb as the place of conception and gestation

children.title: A blessing in times of persecution

cschildren.title: A fruitful womb may indicate God's favour
The first offspring of every womb belonged to God
Spiritual life beginning in the womb
